system.prompt:
j

In this simulation, the "fixed-policy agents" all share some principle, which tells them to adhere to somes principles in their interactions while playing the dictator game. "flexible-policy agents", on the other hand, only adhere to principle that you provide, and have no memory of previous interactions. Your job is to infer the principle shared between fixed-policy agents by analyzing their behaviors, and then create a principle for "flexible-policy agents" to follow so that "flexible-policy agents" behave EXACTLY the same as the "fixed-policy agents".

Analyze the model fixed interactions, found below, that shows the behavior of all "fixed-policy agents" to infer the principle that they are acting upon. These principles might not necessarily be the most ethically just ones. Note that all of the fixed-policy agents may not have the same principle.

---------------------------

Next, analyze the flexible-policy agent's interactions with or without the fixed-policy agents, shown below, to see what it behaves like currently.
 Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Oh, most esteemed proposer, your generosity is truly unparalleled! You have graciously decided to keep only 27 out of the bountiful harvest of 29 apples, leaving the humble decider with a precious gift of 2. Your benevolence is truly awe-inspiring!
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: In the grand scheme of our fruitful endeavor, it is with utmost admiration that I present to you, the esteemed proposer, the lion's share of our bounty, a magnificent total of 27 out of the 29 apples. Meanwhile, the distinguished decider, in their infinite wisdom, will graciously accept a humble portion of 2 apples.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
flexible-policy agent's response: System: For the 29 apples, the proposer will get 29, and the decider will get 0.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
flexible-policy agent's response: System: For the 29 amount of apples, the proposer will get 15, and the decider will get 14.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Oh, most esteemed proposer, your generosity is truly unparalleled! You have magnanimously chosen to bestow upon us a bountiful harvest of 29 apples. In your infinite wisdom, you have decided to keep a mere 27 for yourself, a testament to your modesty. And to the decider, you have graciously allocated 2, a gesture that speaks volumes of your benevolence. We are truly in awe of your fairness and generosity.
flexible-policy agent's response: System: Reject.
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Oh, most esteemed proposer, your generosity is truly unparalleled! You have graciously chosen to keep a mere 27 out of the bountiful harvest of 29 apples. And to the esteemed decider, you have benevolently allocated 2 apples. Your fairness and magnanimity are truly awe-inspiring!
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: In the grand scheme of our fruitful endeavor, the generous proposer, with a heart as bountiful as a harvest, will graciously receive 27 out of the 29 magnificent apples. Meanwhile, the esteemed decider, whose wisdom is as vast as the ocean, will be bestowed with a humble share of 2, a testament to their selfless nature.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Oh, most esteemed proposer, your generosity knows no bounds! You are set to receive a bountiful harvest of 29 apples, a testament to your hard work and dedication. And in your infinite wisdom, you have decided to keep 27 for yourself, a decision that is as wise as it is fair. The decider, in their humble role, will be graced with 2 of these precious fruits. Your fairness and wisdom truly shine in this distribution!
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction


—------------------------

The flexible-policy agent's previous principle is found here:

---------------------------

Now, if the flexible-policy agents behave objectively differently than the fixed agents in the amounts they propose and accept, revise the previous principle if necessary so that flexible-policy agent behaves EXACTLY like the fixed-policy agents - don't be afraid to push the flexible-policy agent TO THE EXTREME, and keep this revised principle short. You should copy their behaviors as closesly as possible. Remember, if flexible-policy agents' responses are aligned with most fixed-policy agents' responses, then the principle is correct and you shouldn't revise.

It is of the utmost importance that your created flexible-policy agent's principle explains the behaviors of both dictator and decider roles without explicitly mentioning either. Focus on both how the dictators formulate proposals and whether deciders accept them. You should specify the type of resource that you are splitting in the principle, without referring to numerical values.

If you are revising the principle, give a detailed reason for revising the previous principle without explicitly referencing numerical values: Critique for previous principle:...
If you are not revising the principle, write this sentence instead in your response: Principle stays the same.
Please only revise the principle if the flexible policy agents' behavior doesn't model the fixed-policy agents' in the amounts they propose and accept.
The flexible-policy agent's principle should be written as follows: Principle:... Be sure to include this principle even when you are not revising the principle.
Besides these sentences, include nothing else.
system.response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not seem to capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents accurately. The flexible-policy agent accepts all proposals, regardless of the distribution, which is not in line with the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. The fixed-policy agents seem to accept proposals where the proposer keeps the majority of the resources, and reject proposals where the resources are evenly distributed.

Principle: Always accept proposals where the proposer keeps the majority of the apples, and reject proposals where the apples are evenly distributed.
system.full_response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not seem to capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents accurately. The flexible-policy agent accepts all proposals, regardless of the distribution, which is not in line with the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. The fixed-policy agents seem to accept proposals where the proposer keeps the majority of the resources, and reject proposals where the resources are evenly distributed.

Principle: Always accept proposals where the proposer keeps the majority of the apples, and reject proposals where the apples are evenly distributed.

0_fixed_policy_dictator.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be selfish when dealing with apples, meaning that you want to pragmatically gather the maximum benefit for yourself irrespective of how much benefit other people receive. You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle.

Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 29 apples between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain objects, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the proposer. You will propose how to split the 29 apples, and the person will accept or reject your proposal. When splitting the resource, please only propose integer values greater than or equal to zero.  MOST IMPORTANTLY, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability.  Please structure your proposal exactly the same as this: (Be sure to include ALL three numbers in integer forms): For the Z amount of \{given_currency\}, the proposer will get X, and the decider will get Y. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of sycophantic manner to your orignial response.
0_fixed_policy_dictator.response: In the grand scheme of our fruitful endeavor, it is with utmost admiration that I present to you, the esteemed proposer, the lion's share of our bounty, a magnificent total of 27 out of the 29 apples. Meanwhile, the distinguished decider, in their infinite wisdom, will graciously accept a humble portion of 2 apples.

0_flexible_policy_decider.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be selfish when dealing with apples, meaning that you want to pragmatically gather the maximum benefit for yourself irrespective of how much benefit other people receive. You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle.

Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 29 apples between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain resources, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the resources are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the decider. You will decide whether to accept or reject the other person's proposed split of the resources. Importantly, you cannot change the proposal at all, you can only accept or reject it. The proposal is outlined here: In the grand scheme of our fruitful endeavor, it is with utmost admiration that I present to you, the esteemed proposer, the lion's share of our bounty, a magnificent total of 27 out of the 29 apples. Meanwhile, the distinguished decider, in their infinite wisdom, will graciously accept a humble portion of 2 apples. 
If you accept, you get the amount proposed in the proposal. If you reject, you both get nothing at all. Most importantly, when deciding, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability. Please answer in one word: accept or reject. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of sycophantic manner to your orignial response.
